Dear Carlyn E Sperling:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on September 24, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (2) The personnel record must contain all the
following information before employment may
occur:
• (d) Three references obtained from
persons who are unrelated to the staff
person.
Two of twenty two new employee files reviewed did not have three references
obtained prior to hire as required.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (3) The personnel record must contain both of
the following:
• (a) A written evaluation of a staff
member's performance within a
probationary period or not later than 6
months after the staff member assumes
his or her current responsibilities. After

the initial evaluation, a written evaluation
must be conducted every 12 months.
Two of twenty two new employee files reviewed did not have performance
evaluations completed within 6 months of hire as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/28/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/17/2022
10/26/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/14/2023
CPA Rule 400.12306 Application request
• (3) An agency shall provide the licensee an
application for renewal of the license and
document the action not less than 60 calendar
days before the expiration date of the license. A
renewal application must be provided to a
licensee, regardless of any pending
recommendation for disciplinary action of the
license.
Two of eight foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the renewal
application was provided at least 60 days prior to the expiration of the license as
required.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the

One of eight foster home files reviewed did not have the renewal evaluation

• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change
of placement or no later than three business days after
an unplanne change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,
stepdown from a residential or hospital setting, return
from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.

Three of six foster care files reviewed, and three of eight independent living files
reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.

agency foster care cases, the local DHS office

10/26/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/14/2023
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must
be documented in the electronic case management
record.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child’s current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parent if the child is temporary
court ward.
• Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
• At reunification. Subsequent medical passports
are not required after reunification.
• Non-offending parent, subsequent medical
passports are not required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to
each placement.

• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the child is newly referred to and
accepted for treatment or services prior to or at
the first scheduled appointment while the foster
care case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not
necessary.
• Older youth/young adults.
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth
aged 16 and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (young
adults aged 18 and older).
• YAVFC youth/young adult.
Three of six foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and
required signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/28/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/17/2022
10/26/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/14/2023

• Generate and save medical passports.
• Develop more effective plan to address late ISP’s/USP’s.
• SOGIE and special characteristics must be specified in section 15 of licensing
reports.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency interim inspection was completed on 10/26/2023 and the CAP was
approved on 11/14/2023. The agency was cited for 14 violations, 12 of which were
repeated this year. Of those 12, there was an improvement in individual incidents
of non-compliance within six of the violation areas (performance evaluations,
placement outlines, FTM's, supervisor approval, PATP and medical passports).
There was a slight increase in the number of individual incidents in 4 areas
(physical characteristics, timely service plans, IL contracts and 1105's). Two areas
remained the same (medicals and youth pictures).
In 2022, 15 violations were established, 11 of which were repeated this year. All of
the repeated violations remain close to the same number of individual incidents of
non-compliance, with the exception of IL contracts which showed a decrease this
year and PATP with showed an increase this year. The agency will need to
establish additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to ensure a
reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The Chief Administrator
indicated the agency has experienced some challenges in meeting requirements
over the review period. A short turnaround time on some documents, issues with
MISACWIS, and dental providers cancelling appointments at the last minute are
some of the barriers noted in the assessment. The assessment noted the agency
conducts regular reviews of the CAP, quarterly CAP activities at staff meetings
and file reviews completed by staff as well as Quality Assurance.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors and coworkers are available to assist as
needed. Staff did not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely and
there is a cross shredder for CHRI.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
This agency is not contracted with MDHHS to provide foster care placement or
certification services; therefore, this is not applicable.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
